Fuzzy rugs absorb sound. That's not a revolutionary discovery. The application is though. Maybe that's another technology that could be developed for stealth technology or dampening sonic booms.

Owls also have some sound dampening in the inside of their wings to avoid the feathers to give their position to the prey when gliding. The air passing through these fluffy specialized feathers makes a lot less noise. Well there are several problems the coral face aside from bleaching (usually caused by ocean levels and temperature increase). The acidificiation or the decrease in ph in the oceans is partially caused by global climate change, but it's also caused by the increase of nitrates and nitrites from agriculture. On top of that over fishing and climate issues also create mass growth of competitive and predatory inverts and algae. Corals for the most part are on their way out, along with most of the ocean's species. The ecological collapse of the earth's oceans is one of the biggest global disasters we face that will coincide and partially be caused by global climate change.


Fun fact though, throughout the Phanerazoic (the current eon we are in, IE the past 500+ million years in earth biological history), most reefs in the fossil record were not built by corals. The earliest known reefs were built by planktonic microscopic organisms, sponges, algae and even a few built by clams in the Mesozoic, were the primary reef builders. While corals have existed since the Cambrian, most were solitary species, a bit different than the colonial corals we are more familiar with in a reef setting (although solitary corals still exist). Coral reefs didn't start to become a major ecological system, until roughly 20-30 million years ago.


The one bit of good news is that corals have had a long history of depletion and reemergence. Hopefully they don't go the way of the Trilobite, and continue on long after our cockroach overlords take over the world after we nuke ourselves out of civilization.

The news about furry moths is astonishing to me, mostly because I’ve believed it for years.  When I was a kid learning about insects from my mom she taught me the differences between butterflies and moths (restring wing angle, antenna shape, and “furriness”) I asked “why are moths furry” and she told me that it was because moths fly and night and bats hunt them, so the fur muffled the bats’ echolocation,  but since butterflies fly during the day they don’t need to hide from bats, thus have no fur.  She told me this in the mid-1970’s, and I always just assumed it to be true, the way kids often take their parents’ word on blind faith, and I had no idea that she just sort of made it up.  (Unfortunately she died this past May so I can’t ask her about this)
Zooxanthellae are not classified as algae, they used to be. They are now in the group “Alveolata” and they are single celled photosynthetic dinoflagellates.
